Award.AwardTitle: EMSW21-RTG: Enhanced Training and Recruitment in Mathematical Biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research and Training Grant will use the mathematical biology program of the Mathematics Department at Duke University to enhance the recruitment of American nationals into the mathematical sciences. The goals are to attract more excellent undergraduates into mathematical biology, to provide excellent and expanded training of mathematical biologists at the graduate level, and to increase the diversity of research experiences of young post-Ph.D. mathematical biologists. The undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows will be integrated into one or more of the six vertically integrated interdisciplinary research groups in the Mathematics Department: (1) Kidney physiology (Harold and Anita Layton); (2) Electrophysiology of the heart (David Schaeffer); (3) Systems biology and genomics (John Harer); (4) Image segmentation and dorsal closure (Stephanos Venakides); (5) Mathematical models of cell metabolism (Michael Reed); (6) Data driven inference and biological structure (Jonathan Mattingly). The faculty members in the six research groups have very good track records in successful mentoring of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral research projects, as well as recruiting and training women and other under-represented groups. The success of these mentoring and recruitment activities is an important priority for these faculty members and is the central goal of this Research Training Grant.

To achieve the goals of the program, the undergraduates will conduct research in the summers mentored by program faculty, more graduate students will be recruited and trained in new graduate courses, and postdoctoral fellows will conduct research with program faculty. In addition, each year there will be a summer workshop that targets students at small colleges in the Southeast who may have little knowledge about graduate degrees and few opportunities to study mathematical biology. A particular goal of the program is to recruit women and other under-represented groups into the mathematical sciences. Because of the many faculty members conducting research in mathematical biology, and the proximity of the Duke Medical Center and the Duke School of the Environment, the Mathematics Department at Duke is an excellent location to study mathematical biology and to achieve the goal of attracting American nationals into the mathematical sciences.

ProgramReference.Text: RES TRAINING GROUPS IN THE MATH SCIENCES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to train American nationals to conduct research in mathematical biology and to encourage American nationals to go to graduate school in the STEM disciplines. The grant trained 4 Postdoctoral fellows. These Fellows now have jobs at the Colorado School of Mines, The College of William and Mary, The FDA Lab in Little Rock, and Duke University. 22 graduate students received partial support from the grant of which 8 have received the Ph.D. and 4 more Ph.D’s are expected this year. 40 undergraduate students worked on 6-8 week summer research projects. Another 75 undergraduate students from small colleges attended 10-day workshops on mathematical biology designed to encourage them to pursue careers in the STEM disciplines.

     A particular point of emphasis in our program was to train the Fellows, the graduate students, and the undergraduates as complete professionals. We trained them to work cooperatively, to write well, to learn to give excellent public lectures with slides, and to accept their responsibilities to contribute to the entire scientific enterprise, not just their own personal advancement.

     The grant had considerable impact beyond this training program. For seven years, funds from the grant were used to bring researchers from other universities and medical centers to Duke to give lectures on their work in the weekly colloquium.  Many faculty members, postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduates not supported by the grant attended and benefitted from these lectures and many new collaborations were formed. In addition, our faculty visitors program brought prominent faculty members from other institutions to Duke for longer visits to enhance the research training of the Fellows and graduate students. The colloquium visitors and the visiting faculty members learned and helped to spread our innovative training methods throughout the mathematics community.

     Two particular innovations were very successful.  The first was the ``colloquium seminar’’ that would meet two days before each colloquium. Two graduate students would be assigned the task of presenting the speaker’s research program to the other graduate students with the help of a postdoctoral or faculty mentor. Then, after the colloquium, these two graduate students would organize the lunch for the speaker, no faculty members allowed. Because of the colloquium seminar all the graduate students and the postdoctoral fellows were better prepared for the colloquium. The presenting graduate students got good practice in working together, in public speaking, and in slide preparation. At the lunch, the graduate students and postdoctoral fellows learned how to discuss their own work with visiting scientists and mathematicians. Over the course of this grant, the graduate students reported that the colloquium seminar was key for their professional development. 

      The second successful innovation was the mathematical biology Workshops for students from (non-prestigious) small colleges and universities. Such students often have intellectual and social anxiety about going to graduate school at a prestigious institution. We brought them to Duke for 10 days in which they would hear lectures, conduct research in teams with graduate student or postdoctoral mentors and deliver lectures on their work. The students had fun and got know graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and faculty members so they could envision a potential professional path for themselves, and they heard panel discussions on applying to graduate school and non-academic careers with a BS or PhD.  The evaluation reports showed a dramatic positive change in the students’ intentions about applying to graduate school in the STEM discipline because of the Workshop. In 2017, a particular emphasis of the Workshop was to recruit students from the Historically Black Colleges and Universities.
